awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research:  Advanced Algorithmic Tools for Discovery in Cognitive Radio Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The prevalence of embedded computing and wireless technology has given rise to remarkable new opportunities for technology to provide and improve safety and services. Such applications include on-the-fly traffic management to improve safety and reduce congestion, establishing ad-hoc networks for disaster recovery, and maintaining sensor networks for military or scientific purposes. In all these cases, wireless devices must discover each other's existence, configure their wireless radios to maximize efficiency, and conserve battery power. This project will develop new methods to address these fundamental problems of discovery and efficiency. Additionally, the project will develop and new techniques and tools for evaluating the efficacy of proposed solutions. The project also incorporates development of undergraduate- and graduate-level courses, outreach via educational opportunities for high-school teachers and students, expanding participation of undergraduates and underrepresented groups in research, and support for female students in computing.

This project aims to develop and analyze advanced algorithmic tools for spatio-temporal peer discovery, a fundamental primitive for ad-hoc networks. The proposal focuses on cognitive radio networks characterized by high mobility, congested spectrum, motion-induced channel outages and energy-constrained commodity devices. The development of efficient discovery schemes with both provable guarantees and strong practical performance will be critical for the build out of such networks for large scale applications such as road safety and emergency response for driver-less fleets. The project has four principal thrusts: (1) Multi-channel discovery, where nodes equipped with spectrally agile radios channel hop to achieve rendezvous using deterministic and probabilistic techniques for achieving multi-channel discovery, drawing inspiration from constructive Ramsey theory, cyclic algebraic geometry codes, number theoretic sieves, and a novel pseudo-random construction: the synchronizing sampler; (2) Energy-constrained single channel discovery algorithms where mobile nodes duty cycle to save battery, via connections with additive combinatorics, algebraic geometry, and expander graphs; (3) Spatial discovery through signal strength by applying techniques from computational and convex geometry for estimations of trajectories within vehicular environments; and (4) Validation via a simulation environment using the ns-3 simulator with appropriate extensions for multi-channel vehicular networks. While focusing on vehicular networks, these techniques can be applied in a wide variety of different networks, such as medical and telemetry networks as well.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:
1.We have studied the complexity of rendezvous, discovery, and synchronization in both the "named" and "anonymous" models. Our setting of interest arises when devices must rendezvous in a multi-channel environment where each device is constrained to operate on only a subset of the channels. We have developed a broadly-applicable transformation that yields an anonymous synchronization/discovery algorithm (in the multi-channel case) from a discovery algorithm that requires individual names for the devices. Specifically, a significant body of previous work provides multi-channel discovery algorithms (in our setting of interest where each device is restricted to a particular subset of the available channels) under the strong assumption that each device has a fairly short name/identifier that is distinct from all other devices (this is useful in the discovery algorithm because it can break symmetry). We have shown how to adapt the algorithms from our 2014 ICDCS paper--which do not require such identifiers--to achieve results comparable with these algorithms. Moreover, we propose a general number-theoretic transformation that can carry out this process for arbitrary algorithms in the "named" model. Note that the anonymous model is useful in situations where the devices that wish to rendezvous come from a large population, or are the result of a homogeneous manufacturing process.2. We developed a new class of erasure codes with applications to the problem of secure archival storage. We show connections of these codes to a new uncertainty-theorem for the setting of the cyclic groups over finite fields 
3. We investigated a generalized notion of adversariality through a unified framework for strategic classification and introduced the notion of strategic VC-dimension (SVC) to capture the PAC-learnability in our general strategic setup. We instantiated our framework for the fundamental strategic linear classification problem. We fully characterized: (1) the statistical learnability of linear classifiers by pinning down its SVC; (2) it's computational tractability by pinning down the complexity of the empirical risk minimization problem. Our paper got accepted to ICML'21.
4. We initiated a study of the problem of generating constrained codes for scanning technologies using deep networks. Our work resulted in the filing of a provisional patent and we are in talks with a startup to license the technology.   
5. We initiated the algorithmic study of retracting a graph into a cycle in the graph, which seeks a mapping of the graph vertices to the cycle vertices so as to minimize the maximum stretch of any edge, subject to the constraint that the restriction of the mapping to the cycle is the identity map. This problem has its roots in the rich theory of retraction of topological spaces, and has strong ties to well-studied metric embedding problems such as minimum bandwidth and0-extension. Our first result is anO(min{k,√n})-approximation for retracting any graph onnnodes to a cycle withk nodes. We also show a surprising connection to Sperner’s Lemma that rules out the possibility of improving this result using certain natural convex relaxations of the problem.Broader Impact:
I met regularly with a group of Northeastern grad and undergrad students - Akshar Varma (PhD),  and Tanay Mehta(PhD) and Jack Wilkins (undergrad). Sanjay Badlani (MS),  and Hoyin Chu(undergrad) and Claire Wang (woman, undergrad).  
I am also participating in the Align program at the Khoury College of Computer Sciences, Northeastern University, funded in part by the Gates Foundation, to create a unique path-way for students from diverse backgrounds to Northeastern’s experiential MS in CS. I accepted over 50 Align students (almost all women and minorities) to my MS course on Algorithms in Fall 2019 and Fall 2020 and gave them extra bridge lectures and tutoring sessions.
